title: Spanish Physician

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on canvas.

credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Shapiro
publication_history:
Charles Henri Ford, ed., “Exhibition Max Ernst,” exh. cat. in View, 2, no. 1 (April 1942): 18, cat. 6 (as Spanish doctor, fat horse, and young girl).

Charles Henri Ford, ed., “Drawings and Paintings by Max Ernst,” exh. cat. in View, 2, no. 1 (April 1942): 18, cat. 3 (as Spanish doctor, fat horse, and young girl).

Caresse Crosby Gallery, Max Ernst/Dorothea Tanning, exh. mailer (Washington D.C.: Caresse Crosby Gallery, 1946), n.p. (Spanish Doctor, Fat Horse, and Young Girl).

Martica Sawin, “The Max Ernst Exhibition,” Arts 35, no. 7 (April 1961): 44 (ill.).

Museum of Modern Art, Max Ernst, exh. cat. (Garden City, NY: Doubleday, 1961), 42 (ill), 54, cat. 88.

Tate Gallery, Max Ernst, exh. cat. (London: Arts Council of Great Britain, 1961), 55, cat. 137 (ill.).

Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, Selections from the Joseph Randall Shapiro Collection, exh. cat. (Chicago: Museum of Contemporary Art, 1969), cat. 25 (ill.).

Arts Club of Chicago, The Horse as Motif, 1200 B.C.-1966 A.D., exh. cat. (Chicago: Arts Club of Chicago, 1975), 44–45, cat. 71 (ill.).

Dawn Ades, et. al., Terry Ann R. Neff, ed., In the Mind’s Eye: Dada and Surrealism, exh. cat.
(Chicago: Museum of Contemporary Art, 1985), 11, pl. 3 (color ill.), 147.

Katherine Kuh and Dennis Adrian, The Mr. & Mrs. Joseph Randall Shapiro Collection, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1985), 56, fig. 44, cat. 55 (color ill.). 110, cat. 55.

Werner Spies, Sigrid Metken, and Günter Metken, Max Ernst: Werke 1939–1953 (Houston and Cologne, 1987), 28, cat. 2357 (ill).

Julia Drost, “‘Press hostile or silent, public recalcitrant, zero sales’: Max Ernst at the Valentine Gallery, Spring 1942” in Julia Drost, Fabrice Flahutez, et al., Networking Surrealism in the USA: Agents, Artists, and the Market (Paris and Heidelberg: DFK-Paris, 2019), 192.

Carlos Martin, Tere Arcq, Naja Rasmussen, and Stefan van Raay, Leonora Carrington: Revelation, exh. cat. (Barcelona: RM Verlag, S.L.), 144, cat. 48, 149 (color ill.), 303.

Susan L. Aberth, "Gods and Monsters," Artforum, 61, no. 9 (May 2023), 64.
exhibition_history:
New York, Valentine Gallery, Exhibition Max Ernst, Mar. 23-Apr. 11, 1942, cat. 6 (as Spanish doctor, fat horse and young girl); Arts Club of Chicago, as Drawings and Paintings by Max Ernst, May 22–June 13, 1942, cat 3 (as Spanish doctor, fat horse and young girl). For sale.

Washington, D.C., Caresse Crosby Gallery, Max Ernst/Dorothea Tanning, Mar. 15–Apr. 10, 1946, cat. 7 (as Spanish Doctor, Fat Horse, and Young Girl). For sale. 

Arts Club of Chicago, Surrealism Then and Now, Oct. 1–30, 1958, cat. 20. Lent by “JRS”.

New York, Museum of Modern Art, Max Ernst, Mar. 1–May 7, 1961, cat. 88; traveled to Chicago, Art Institute, June 16–July 23, 1961.

London, Tate Gallery, Max Ernst, Sept. 7–Oct. 15, 1961, cat. 137.

Chicago, Museum of Contemporary Art, Selections from the Joseph Randall Shapiro Collection, Dec. 20, 1969–Feb. 1, 1970, cat. 25.

Arts Club of Chicago, The Horse as Motif, 1200 B.C.-1966 A.D., Jan. 15–Feb. 22, 1975, cat. 71.

Chicago, Museum of Contemporary Art, Dada and Surrealism in Chicago Collections, Dec. 1, 1984–Jan. 27, 1985, no cat. no.

Art Institute of Chicago, The Mr. & Mrs. Joseph Randall Shapiro Collection, Feb. 23–Apr. 14, 1985, cat. 55.

Ishøj, DK, Arken Museum of Modern Art, Lenora Carrington: Revelation, Sept. 17,2022–Jan. 15, 2023, cat. 48; Madrid, Fundación MAPFRE, Feb. 11–May 7, 2023.
provenance_text: The artist, Saint Martin d’Ardèche, France, 1940 [New York 1961] and later New York [New York 1942]; sold through Peggy Guggenheim and Howard Putzel, New York, between 1942 and 1946 [Peggy Guggenheim, Out of this Century (New York: Dial Press, 1946), 310]. With Julien Levy Gallery, New York, by 1946 [handwritten checklist for Washington, D.C. 1946, no. 7, Philadelphia Museum of Art, Library and Archives, Julien Levy Gallery Records; copy in curatorial object file ]. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Randall Shapiro, Oak Park, IL, by 1958 [lender information sheet, Newberry Library, Arts Club Papers, Series I: Exhibitions, Box 55, Folder 716; copy in curatorial object file]; bequeathed to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1996.
